verses.text: When Samuel grew old, he appointed his sons as judges over Israel.
verses.comment: The verse closely follows the Hebrew, mentioning Samuel's sons as judges.

verses.text: Now the name of his firstborn son was Joel, and the name of his second, Abijah; they judged in Beersheba.
verses.comment: Names and location preserved; 'judged' is the literal Hebrew term.

verses.text: But his sons did not walk in his ways. They turned aside after dishonest gain, accepted bribes and perverted justice.
verses.comment: "Turned aside after dishonest gain" matches Hebrew idiom; the listing of their deeds is direct.

verses.text: Then all the elders of Israel gathered together and came to Samuel at Ramah.
verses.comment: No significant deviation; 'elders' refers to tribal leaders.

verses.text: They said to him, "You are old, and your sons do not walk in your ways. Now appoint a king for us to judge us like all the nations."
verses.comment: "Judge us" reflects Hebrew 'shafat', also meaning 'govern.'

verses.text: But the thing displeased Samuel when they said, "Give us a king to judge us." So Samuel prayed to the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Displeased' renders Hebrew 'was evil in Samuel’s eyes.'

verses.text: And the LORD said to Samuel, "Listen to the voice of the people in all that they say to you; for they have not rejected you, but they have rejected Me from being king over them."
verses.comment: Close to Hebrew text; capitalized 'Me' for clarity.

verses.text: "As they have done from the day I brought them up out of Egypt even to this day, forsaking Me and serving other gods, so they are doing to you also."
verses.comment: Direct translation; follows Hebrew word order closely.

verses.text: "Now then, listen to their voice; but you shall solemnly warn them and show them the ways of the king who shall rule over them."
verses.comment: Warn and explain 'ways' (Hebrew 'mishpat')—the expected practices of kings.

verses.text: So Samuel told all the words of the LORD to the people who were asking him for a king.
verses.comment: No significant differences; 'words' as a direct translation.

verses.text: He said, "This will be the way of the king who will reign over you: He will take your sons and appoint them for himself as his chariots and horsemen, and they will run before his chariots."
verses.comment: 'Run before his chariots' means serve as runners or forerunners.

verses.text: "He will appoint for himself commanders of thousands and commanders of fifties, and some to plow his ground and reap his harvest, and to make his weapons of war and equipment for his chariots."
verses.comment: 'Commanders of thousands' and 'fifties' are literal translations of military ranks.

verses.text: "He will take your daughters to be perfumers, cooks, and bakers."
verses.comment: Occupations retained as in Hebrew text.

verses.text: "He will take the best of your fields, your vineyards, and your olive groves, and give them to his servants."
verses.comment: Literal rendering of 'best of your fields'.

verses.text: "He will take a tenth of your grain and of your vineyards and give it to his officials and servants."
verses.comment: "A tenth" is the literal translation for what is commonly 'tithe' elsewhere.

verses.text: "He will take your male servants and your female servants, the best of your young men, and your donkeys, and use them for his work."
verses.comment: Literal translation with no additions; 'young men' follows some Hebrew manuscripts.

verses.text: "He will take a tenth of your flocks, and you yourselves will become his servants."
verses.comment: Consistent with verse 15, 'a tenth' is literal.

verses.text: "And you will cry out because of your king whom you have chosen for yourselves, but the LORD will not answer you in that day."
verses.comment: Direct wording; 'answer you' is literal Hebrew 'hear you.'

verses.text: But the people refused to obey the voice of Samuel. They said, "No! But there shall be a king over us,"
verses.comment: Direct translation of the people's words.

verses.text: "so that we also may be like all the nations, and that our king may judge us and go out before us and fight our battles."
verses.comment: 'Judge us' retains the Hebrew word for govern. The order matches the original.

verses.text: And Samuel listened to all the words of the people and repeated them in the ears of the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Repeated them in the ears' is a literal idiom for 'reported.'

verses.text: And the LORD said to Samuel, "Listen to their voice and make them a king." So Samuel said to the men of Israel, "Each of you go to your city."
verses.comment: The final phrase literally commands the people to return home.
